perturbation.original_text: All subscription funds received by Capital Resources (and if by check shall be made payable to the Company) or by other NASD registered broker-dealers soliciting subscriptions (if any) shall be transmitted (either by U.S. Mail or similar type of transmittal) to the Company by noon of the following business day.
perturbation.changed_text: All subscription funds received by Capital Resources (and if by check shall be made payable to the Company) or by other NASD registered broker-dealers soliciting subscriptions (if any) shall be transmitted (either by U.S. Mail or similar type of transmittal) to the Company within 10 business days of receipt.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text delays the transmission of subscription funds, contradicting regulations that require prompt handling of investor funds.
perturbation.law_explanation: SEC Rule 15c2-4 requires brokers or dealers to promptly transmit or deposit customer funds received in connection with an offering. Allowing for a 10-day delay violates the 'promptly transmit' requirement, potentially endangering investor funds and delaying the offering process.

perturbation.original_text: The Company will make generally available to its security holders as soon as practicable, but not later than 90 days after the close of the period an earnings statement (in form complying with the provisions of Rule 158 under the 1933 Act) covering a twelve-month period beginning not later than the first day of the Company's fiscal quarter next following the effective date (as defined in said Rule 158) of the Registration Statement.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company will make generally available to its security holders no later than 180 days after the close of the period an earnings statement (in form complying with the provisions of Rule 158 under the 1933 Act) covering a twelve-month period beginning not later than the first day of the Company's fiscal quarter next following the effective date (as defined in said Rule 158) of the Registration Statement.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text extends the deadline for providing earnings statements beyond what is generally permissible under SEC rules for timely financial reporting.
perturbation.law_explanation: Companies must file quarterly reports on Form 10-Q. The earnings must be furnished in a timely manner, and extending the deadline to 180 days after the close of the period violates the quarterly reporting requirements and delays important information.

perturbation.original_text: During the period of three years from the date hereof, the Company will furnish to Capital Resources: (i) a copy of each report of the Company furnished to or filed with the Commission under the 1934 Act or any national securities exchange or system on which any class of securities of the Company is listed or quoted (including but not limited to, reports on Form 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K and all proxy statements and annual reports to stockholders), a copy of each report of the Company mailed to its stockholders or filed with the Commission or the OTS or any other supervisory or regulatory authority or any national securities exchange or system on which any class of securities of the Company is listed or quoted, each press release and material news items and additional public documents and information with respect to the Company or the Association as Capital Resources may reasonably request, and (ii) from time to time, such other publicly available information concerning the Company and the Association as Capital Resources may reasonably request.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company may, at its discretion, furnish to Capital Resources a copy of reports of the Company furnished to the Commission under the 1934 Act. The Company is not obligated to provide any specific document or material.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text removes the obligation for the company to provide Capital Resources with reports filed with the SEC, potentially hindering Capital Resources' ability to monitor the company's compliance and performance.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act mandates reporting requirements for publicly traded companies. By removing the firm obligation to provide Capital Resources with these mandatory reports, the modified text hinders transparency and creates a risk of non-compliance with disclosure requirements to Capital Resources during the stock offering.
